reviewText: I pride myself on being a connoisseur of bad movies.  I have purposely watched hundreds upon hundreds of terrible movies with my friends, ranging from classics like Manos: The Hands of Fate to foreign 80's conan ripoffs to the contemporary Sci-Fi Channel and Asylum cheese fests.  But not even those can prepare you for the abomination that is Nukie.  It is, without doubt, the worst movie I have ever seen.  By worst I do not mean least enjoyable; there are horrifically boring movies that are less enjoyable than Nukie.  By worst I mean it causes more pain.  To be honest, I can't put into words exactly what that is.  There are movies that are more ridiculous.  There are movies that have worse costumes.  There are movies that have more annoying characters (though perhaps not many).  There are even movies with stupider plots.  But somehow, by some inexplicable alignment of terribleness, all these things have combined like an evil, mutated Captain Planet into Nukie, which has the power to punch your soul and beat it until you lose all faith in humanity and the universe.Nukie is a movie about two alien light beams which inexplicably speak english and crash land on Earth because they are ungodly stupid.  Upon landing on earth they transform into hideously disfigured E.T. knockoffs that are, for reasons unknown to anyone who has the slightest claim to humanity, expected to be seen as cute by the audience.  One of them is named Nico and is captured by American scientists, who apparently operate out of a low-rent apartment building in Miami.  The other is named Nukie, who lands in Africa and is so stupid he never considers just flying over to America even though he has no trouble flying anywhere else.  Nukie and Nico spend the first fifteen minutes of the movie yelling each others names back and forth by bouncing their voices off of the moon.  Yes, that makes just as much sense written down as it does in the movie.  Nico is experimented on by scientists before being helped by a sentient computer who wants to turn scientists into clowns and have disco dance parties in his laboratory.  Meanwhile, Nukie tries to convince the African natives to help him get to America by terrorizing them, breaking their things, crashing a helicopter, and causing two little boys to be cast out into the wild.  For some reason, this doesn't make them want to help him, so Nukie is forced to wander through stock footage and before befriending a talking monkey who has a fondness for candy and stupidity.  Nukie finds the children and celebrates by flying around in the sky, not going to America, and doing a disco dance scene in the African wilderness.I have now seen this movie four times, and every time it takes a piece of my soul back to hell with it.  There are no words that can adequately describe what viewing this movie does to you.  Some have said it is like watching a train wreck, in that you have to keep watching even though it is horrible.  It is more like watching the annihilation of humanity.  Nukie is nihilism.  Nukie saps you of the will to live and leaves you wandering though the void of nothingness, for after seeing it you know in your heart that there cannot possibly be meaning in a universe which contains Nukie.  There are some things that happen to you in life that change who you are forever.  Nukie is one of those things.

reviewText: I don't care what the rating above says, this movie is like minus 2642346745734454734645546458578 to the 3764784565856575765 power stars.This movie HURT me. (...) said 'every second of this movie is like having a root canal performed on your genitals with rusty dental tools that are also on fire...for the record that's bad.' This description doesn't even begin to capture the mind shattering trauma that will be inflicted upon you by this 'film.'It's not even mock-able or enjoyable on an ironic level. Even with alcohol in your system it's not. A part of me is gone now and it will never return.On the upside every single other thing that ever happens to you in life after this movie from getting herpes to being paralyzed in a freak whacker accident will be that much easier to deal with.

reviewText: I saw this movie while spending the night at a friend's house.PlotHere's the rundown. Two aliens, Nukie and Miko, crash down on Earth. Miko is immediately captured by scientists working for the "Space Foundation" (which for some reason has NASA logos all over it), while Nukie crashes somewhere in the middle of Africa. Miko is put through a number of scientific tests, in a severely weakened condition, telepathically calling for his alien friend Nukie when he can muster the strength (or at least I think he's calling telepathically.. maybe he's just moaning the name). Nukie befriends two young boys from a local tribe, and they help him on his journey to find Miko. On their journey they have to avoid an American helicopter pilot, working for the "Space Foundation", as well as a weird nun (played by Glynis Johns). Miko manages to gain the strength to get off the table, and into the computer room. The "Space Foundation" has a very intelligent computer, that has a plastic and cardboard exterior. The computer is very interested to learn about love and friendship. Miko uses his amazing friend-making abilities to teach the computer about the wonderful world of emotions. Miko decides then to get back in the cell for more wonderfully painful tests. The only non-sadistic scientist working for the "Space Foundation" helps Miko escape.Sound and MusicThe music and voices have their own appeal, sounding like they're coming from a tin can... or at least that's how it sounded on the copy we watched. I expected this much from the movie, since it's very low budget. The music is your standard cheesey children's story music, with flutes and violins.Special EffectsWell, they're really not that special. The effects are cheap for 1993. The most spectacular effect (if that's what you'd want to call it) is when Nukie found his power again, and is on the hilltop playing with streams of energy, which look like cheap cartoon animation. And it all goes downhill from there. Nukie and Miko's costumes are possibly the ugilest excuses for aliens ever. Lumpy brown bodies, with big heads, big ears, and big runny noses.OverallNormally movies of this caliber should be recycled immediately, however this one is a rare find. So it's a collector's item. It's also a good party movie, so you can show your friends "The worst movie ever made". Just be sure to turn it off when they become nauseous.

reviewText: I admit there are significant technical roughnesses in this movie, but it's beyond me how they've managed to overshadow the concept, the beauty and the characters in "Nukie" to the point where it's so unappreciated.  Two aliens, Nukie and Miko, who are able to travel through space without a vessel, by means of some kind of mind-controlled energy abilities, perhaps even transformation into energy or thought, end up 'crashlanding' on different parts of the Earth, with one being captured by a paranoid military and the other setting out on a crossglobal trek to find him with the help of some benevolent humans he encounters.There is an....'effect' that the aliens have on computers that many will find very corny and others will find deep and moving; personally I'm of the latter perception but probably in the minority.  I find this effect (which I don't want to reveal) suggestive of the Nukie and Miko characters being possibly privy to, or part of, a larger or different reality than humanity is aware of, or of the fact that maybe human perceptions of what's going on in the world around them are wrong and even stifling the natural flow of being on this planet.  Others will just find it patently implausible, I suppose, but I feel there's something significant and worth exploring in the scene.The 2 aliens are highly memorable and captivating, and both the bad and good of humanity are represented.  There is even some hint that some of the more cynical, cold types may be learning something from the benevolence of these strange lifeforms without knowing it.  All in all,it succeeds marvelously as a unique picture in my opinion, despite the aforementioned technical shortcomings.To the person on the review board looking for some actual information on the movie and requesting that everybody who's on the page not even talking about the film and just joking around could maybe offer an actual opinion on "Nukie", I sincerely hope this is helpful.  I usually just give my own take on a movie, but I've tried in this case to point out ways in which others might not be as enthralled by "Nukie" as I was, so as to give someone reading an honest chance to decide if they might want to give it a try, seeing as how there's virtually no information on the web or elsewhere about this sadly forgotten film.  Personally I think it's great, and deserves a wider audience.  Recommended for all ages.
summary: Great Movie In The Vein Of E.T.
